ygData.subject: Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
ygData.msgSnippet: I don t know really. I never used Jason s code. I suggest you write your own NEAT system and then extend it to HyperNEAT or just extend the Ken s rtNEAT code

I don't know really. I never used Jason's code. I suggest you write 
your o=
wn NEAT system and then extend it to HyperNEAT or just extend 
the Ken's rt=
NEAT code to HyperNEAT as I have already done. So you will 
be sure that th=
ere are no bugs and shit. I am pretty sure that Jason's 
code is free of bu=
gs, but I have no personal experience with it to be 
able to give any answe=
rs concerning it. I hope that your problem is 
something tiny and can be fi=
xed quickly. I doubt it is something like 
a general design issue and/or a =
bug. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>=

> > Well yes this is exactly what it has to be. Note that randomChoice 
ha=
s
> > to be random every time you refer to it. If it is not random (i.e.
> =
> outside the big loop) then you choose links from either parent. 
But if
>=
 > it is inside the loop, then you choose a gene randomly from either
> > p=
arent. Check this out and you will have a clearer picture if 
there is
> > =
a bug or not. 
> 
> Thanks Petar. I am confident that HyperNEAT 2.5 chooses=
 the parent 
outside
> the loop, and thus grabs all links from either paren=
t1 or parent2. 
What I am
> trying to find out is whether this is by design=
, or if it is a bug.
> 
> Do you (or anyone else) happen to know how it wor=
ks in other NEAT 
packages,
> in particular Ken's original NEAT code? My gu=
ess is that we are 
supposed to
> be grabbing some links from parent1 and s=
ome other links from 
parent2,
> instead of one or the other. I can go chec=
k those packages, of 
course, but I
> won't be able to do that for a little=
 while and was wondering if any 
of you
> knew off the top of your heads.
>=
 
> > But the cloning issue is a deeper one. In this case you must 
ensure
=
> > that individuals should not mate with themselves or such ones that
> > =
have zero compatibility distance. Or at least try a few hundred 
times
> > =
to find a different mate :) Hey, I say this to all users. Don't 
use
> > ra=
nd(), fuck that, use the Mersenne Twister instead. I noticed 
that in
> > e=
nhances performance!
> 
> Fair enough, but right now I am more focused on t=
he more immediate 
issue
> above. Thanks for the suggestions, though. I wil=
l delve into them 
when I
> resolve the other issue.
> 
> Thanks. Jeff. 
> =
> 
> > Peter
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wro=
te:
> >> 
> >> Hi Petar-
> >> 
> >> Thanks for the reply. I do not have a (=
non-HyperNEAT) NEAT 
package
> > around.
> >> Can you let me know if your N=
EAT implementation is different than
> > what I
> >> report below?
> >> 
> =
>> I am using Jason's HyperNEAT 2.5 package available here:
> >> 
> >> http=
://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html
> >> 
> >> If you download the package, t=
he key file is:
> >> HyperNEAT/NEAT/src/NEAT_GeneticIndividual.cpp
> >> 
> =
>> I am attaching it, but I don't know how that works with the yahoo
> > gr=
oup.
> >> 
> >> Crossover occurs in this constructor:
> >> 
> >>     
> > G=
eneticIndividual::GeneticIndividual(shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual>
> >> pare=
nt1,shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual> parent2,bool
> > mate_multipoint_avg)
> >=
> 
> >> The following line occurs outside of the loop that goes through 
ea=
ch
> > link:
> >> 
> >>  bool chooseFirstParent =3D (randomChoice<=3Dparent=
1->getFitness());
> >>  
> >> Then, inside the loop for each link:
> >> 
> =
>>                     if (chooseFirstParent)
> >>                     {
> =
>>                         addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link1));
> >>          =
           }
> >>                     else
> >>                     {
> >> =
                        addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));
> >>             =
        }
> >>  
> >> So, it seems that *all* the links will be grabbed fro=
m one parent 
or
> > the
> >> other. Is that how it works in other versions=
 of NEAT?
> >> 
> >>

"neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>

> Subject: [neat] Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and
> > PNEAT?
=
> >>> 
> >>> Hi Jeff, 
> >>> 
> >>> Well I don't know about the exact imple=
mentations of HyperNEAT 
you
> > are
> >>> using (note that P-NEAT is just =
NEAT with additive mutations
> >>> disabled), but in principle crossover sh=
ould choose genes 
randomly
> >>> from both parents as it builds the offspr=
ing genome, the child. 
In
> >>> HyperNEAT the crossover is different, ther=
e you actually do a
> > regular
> >>> NEAT evolution of networks that build=
 other networks based on 
the
> >>> substrate configuration. That is, you o=
nly mate and mutate the
> > CPPNs.
> >>> But in the case you get lots of in=
dividuals with equal fitness, 
I
> >>> guess these individuals are clones. =
Perhaps the code frequently
> >>> chooses the same individuals for mating? =
You can try to avoid 
this
> > by
> >>> introducing a loop in which you try=
 candidates for a "father" 
that
> > are
> >>> not compatible with the moth=
er, that is, when their 
compatibility
> >>> distance is 0.00, try again. T=
here is another possibility, 
simply
> >>> every mutation disturbs the CPPN=
 and therefore the produced
> > network is
> >>> changed in such a magnitud=
e that is has no chance for survival 
and
> > is
> >>> discarded. Even thou=
gh there is speciation.
> >>> 
> >>> Peter
> >>> 
> >>> 
> >>> --- In neat@=
yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >>>> 
> >>>> Hello all-
> >>=
>> 
> >>>> Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
> >>>> 
> >>>=
> PNEAT:
> >>>> If I am reading the code correctly, during crossover, if th=
e
> >>> substrates are
> >>>> the same (i.e. all links have the same ID), w=
hich is always the
> > case
> >>> in
> >>>> P-NEAT, *all* of the link value=
s are taken from either parent1 
or
> >>> parent2.
> >>>> Isn't it more nor=
mal when crossing over to take some from 
parent1
> >>> and some
> >>>> fro=
m parent2? Why grab all from just one?
> >>>> 
> >>>> This means that in PN=
EAT crossover does nothing, right? It will
> >>> always grab
> >>>> the sub=
strate of parent1 or the substrate of parent2.  If I 
track
> >>> parent an=
d
> >>>> offspring fitness, 100% of the time the child has the exact 
same
=
> >>> fitness as
> >>>> one of the two parents.
> >>>> 
> >>>> On to HyperN=
EAT:
> >>>> 
> >>>> I tracked the fitness of each parent and the resulting =

offspring.
> >>> The odd
> >>>> thing is that the organisms that are cross=
ed only (i.e. they 
are
> >>> never
> >>>> mutated) have the *exact* same f=
itness of one of their parents
> >>> 98.88% of the
> >>>> time. In 20 runs,=
 that was only 136 orgs out of 12257 that were
> >>> crossed over
> >>>> an=
d not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would these
> > new
> >>> =
links
> >>>> have such a small impact? It turns out that this is because
> =
> nearly
> >>> every
> >>>> time that there is an extra link that gets plac=
ed in the child,
> > the
> >>> parent
> >>>> that donated that link is also=
 the parent whose weights are 
being
> >>> grabbed,
> >>>> meaning that the=
 crossover is only copying the parent (hence 
the
> >>> same
> >>>> fitness=
). It seems to me that crossover should be much more
> >>> disruptive, no?
=
> >>>> 
> >>>> 
> >>>> As a final test, I did a set of hyperneat and pneat =
runs with 
the
> >>> default
> >>>> 'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter set t=
o .25, so 25% of orgs
> > never
> >>> are
> >>>> candidates for crossover. =
I then ran experimental treatments
> >>>> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCro=
ss where the
> > MutateOnlyProbability
> >>>> parameter was set to 1, so no=
 orgs were crossed over. Despite 
my
> >>> comments
> >>>> above, Hyperneat=
 (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross, 
however
> >>> the
> >>>> differe=
nce was not tremendous (although it does seem to be
> >>> statistically
> >=
>>> significant). For p-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheless,
> > this
=
> >>> is not a
> >>>> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends, bec=
ause if
> >>> crossover does
> >>>> nothing most of the time, and I increas=
e MutateOnlyProbability
> > from
> >>> .25 to
> >>>> 1, I have effectively =
raised the mutation rate (only 80% of
> > crossed
> >>> orgs are
> >>>> als=
o mutated).
> >>>> 
> >>>> Are these the intended consequences of crossover=
, or am I 
missing
> >>> something?
> >>>> 
> >>>> Cheers,
> >>>> Jeff Clun=
e
> >>>> 
> >>>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

 >>>> jclune@
